data.title: Hitting Enter on html attribute doesent make autocomplete.
data.body:
When I try to choose the html attribute, I have to click on it, and not hit Tab or Enter.

Other editors do that by just hitting Enter.

![sans titre](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2527234/8558535/bb6ffac2-24fc-11e5-9a29-5064525502a8.png)

data.title: Error on launch - LESS / ThemeManager related?
data.body:
I have an error upon launching Atom on Mac OS 10.10.3. It appears to be related to the ThemeManager, but I'm not familiar enough to troubleshoot on my own. I have been using Atom for several months without problems, and just ran into this problem today. I'm unable to do open any files or preferences in app. Rest of system seems ok. I have reinstalled with no improvements.

Here's what shows up in the console:

```
Error
    at new Parser (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/less-cache/node_modules/less/lib/less/parser.js:333:27)
    at LessCache.module.exports.LessCache.parseLess (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/less-cache/lib/less-cache.js:244:16)
    at LessCache.module.exports.LessCache.cssForFile (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/less-cache/lib/less-cache.js:275:20)
    at LessCache.module.exports.LessCache.readFileSync (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/node_modules/less-cache/lib/less-cache.js:263:19)
    at LessCompileCache.module.exports.LessCompileCache.read (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/less-compile-cache.js:36:25)
    at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.loadLessStylesheet (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/theme-manager.js:310:33)
    at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.loadStylesheet (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/theme-manager.js:286:21)
    at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.requireStylesheet (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/theme-manager.js:203:24)
    at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.reloadBaseStylesheets (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/theme-manager.js:266:12)
    at ThemeManager.module.exports.ThemeManager.loadBaseStylesheets (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/theme-manager.js:261:19)index.js:66 handleSetupError
```

data.title: 'atom is not defined' is thrown when opening an 'atom://' URL
data.body:
Whenever I try to open an 'atom://' URL, I get this exception in the console:

```
ReferenceError: atom is not defined
    at Function.module.exports.Package.isBundledPackagePath (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/package.coffee:31:11)
    at Function.module.exports.Package.loadMetadata (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/package.coffee:61:16)
    at PackageManager.module.exports.PackageManager.getAvailablePackageMetadata (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/package-manager.coffee:252:128)
    at AtomApplication.module.exports.AtomApplication.openUrl (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/browser/atom-application.coffee:769:35)
    at EventEmitter.<anonymous> (/Users/alivneh/atom/src/browser/atom-application.coffee:406:24)
    at emitTwo (events.js:87:13)
    at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:169:7)
'
```

Apparently atom is not defined in https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/5dee3ce5950d972d3f275ad1a93d62f542d42aeb/src/package.coffee#L22. Interestingly, atomApplication is defined and contains the properties needed by isBundledPackagePath().
Simply adding `atom = global.atom || global.atomApplication` at the beginning of isBundledPackagePath() fixes this, but there may be an underlying issue that needs to be addressed here.

data.title: Subpixel antialiasing isn't consistently applied to all text in document
data.body:
- Using Atom 1.0.0.
- Using Windows 7.
- The effect seems to happen on both of my monitors:
  - Primary monitor is 1920 x 1200 resolution.
  - Secondary monitor is 1280 x 1024 resolution.
- Using One Light for both UI Theme and Syntax Theme, but it also happens if I use Atom Light on both.
- Running atom --safe didn't make any difference (still has the same alternating blurry).

It seems that when editing some files, that subpixel antialiasing works for a couple lines, then doesn't work for a couple lines, then works for a few lines, then doesn't ...

![capture](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2823875/8557202/d571b2b8-24c9-11e5-99bf-943a2534d034.PNG)

When you zoom in, you can see that lines 34-36 are working properly, but then line 37 doesn't have subpixel antialiasing applied.

![zoom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2823875/8557209/e045b1e4-24c9-11e5-9091-ad139468970c.PNG)

The strange thing is that if I make a document of all "a" characters, for example, it _all_ looks blurry, but at least it is consistent.

![all_blurry](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2823875/8557246/0fb76292-24ca-11e5-8ea5-ba900a1b890b.PNG)

If I fill the document with all "0" characters, it looks like the top few lines are blurry, but the rest renders correctly.

data.title: How to use Split Up/Down/Left/Right Commands?
data.body:
![ingest - atom 2015-07-07 13-38-31](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5841107/8556685/77f3660c-24ad-11e5-9bdd-a0c8b579bbc8.png)

I can't for the life of me reliably trigger this. At all. I assume this means to press Command + K + Right arrow at the same time? That's what feels natural to me anyway. Plus other arrow keys for other split orientations.

I can spam the combination and it works most of the time.

What's up?

data.title: Handle native chromium undo, redo, cut, copy, paste, selectAll on all platforms
data.body:
Our current approach relies on `menu.sendActionToFirstResponder`, which is only defined on OS X. It would be good to actually make this work elsewhere, but this will at least prevent the exception for the undefined method.

Closes #6587

data.title: Validate atom.notifications input
data.body:
Previously the API documented on `atom.notifications` was not validated so you could create a notification with a non-string message, non-object options, or non-string detail. 

This would cause the notifications package to throw errors when it tried to convert a non-string markdown message.

Now it verifies the options on creation and throws error when they are invalid.

Closes https://github.com/atom/notifications/issues/79

/cc @benogle

data.title: Guard against non-string messages in Pane.handleSaveError
data.body:
See https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/7717#issuecomment-119280666 for context. 

cc @kevinsawicki :zap: for catching that case as well

data.title: Add 'name' arg docs to PackageManager functions
data.body: Add missing `name` argument to `enablePackage` and `disablePackage` docs.

data.title: Overriding core keybindings
data.body:
I'm trying to add the following keybindings but they don't seem to work:

```
'atom-workspace atom-text-editor:not([mini])':
    'cmd-T': 'application:new-file'
    'cmd-N': 'application:new-window'
```

According to this answer - https://discuss.atom.io/t/overriding-core-keybindings/10180/7, it may be related to the weight of the selector but I'm not really sure what specificity can help make it stronger.

On a side note, since this is CSS-inspired, what about adding the `!important` keyword?  That way it will override no matter how weak the specificity of the selector is.

data.title: installing packages on Windows with Mingw-64
data.body:
Hello,

I would like to have Atom+Hydrogen working nicely with Winpython, which include a compiler Mingw-64.

Unfortunately, it seems the compilation steps, when installing Hydrogen, tries to use VisualStudio (as I see a `.vcproj`in the long error report.
Is there any workaround to have it compiled with Mingw-64  ?

```
[Enter steps to reproduce below:]

1. install a Winpython
2. unzip an atom-windows.zip in the subdirectory \tools\Atom (so we have `\tools\Atom\atom.exe`
3. modify the \scripts\env.bat file to add `%WINPYDIR%\..\tools\Atom` in the PATH 
4. launch `\scripts\cmd.bat` and then type Atom <Enter> .... Atom launches itself
5. modify default settings to subdirectory `\settings\github` 
6. ask to install Hydrogen, and then ...
```

data.title: Preserve CSON formatting
data.body:
This one may be a long shot, but I'd still like to mention it.  Is there any way to preserve the formatting of a CSON configuration file whenever Atom needs to write and save to it?

The reason I mention it, is because I'm a big fan of having comments in config files so I know what each config does, and it also helps with organization and readability.

Say this is my `config.cson`

``` cson
#
# Config
#

'*':
    # --- MAIN ---

    # WELCOME
    welcome:
        showOnStartup: false

    # CORE
    core:
        disabledPackages: [
            'autocomplete-plus'
            'wrap-guide'
        ]
        themes: [
            'one-dark-ui'
            'solarized-dark-syntax'
        ]

    # EDITOR
    editor:
        invisibles: {}
        tabLength: 4


    # --- PACKAGES ---

    # REPORTING
    'exception-reporting':
        userId: 'ddaafd07-dffd-b252-48db-612909a97759'

    # BRACKET MATCHER
    'bracket-matcher':
        autocompleteBrackets: false
        autocompleteSmartQuotes: false

    # WHITESPACE
    whitespace:
        ensureSingleTrailingNewline: false
```

Once Atom saves it, it's changed to this:

``` cson
"*":
  welcome:
    showOnStartup: false
  core:
    disabledPackages: [
      "autocomplete-plus"
      "wrap-guide"
    ]
    themes: [
      "one-dark-ui"
      "solarized-dark-syntax"
    ]
  editor:
    invisibles: {}
    tabLength: 4
  "exception-reporting":
    userId: "ddaafd07-dffd-b252-48db-612909a97759"
  "bracket-matcher":
    autocompleteBrackets: false
    autocompleteSmartQuotes: false
  whitespace:
    ensureSingleTrailingNewline: false
```

I completely understand the reason for why it happens, which is why I said it's a long shot.  But I think one of the nice things about having our own custom configs is being able to organize it the way we want, so if there could be any way to preserve it that would be great.

data.title: Show hidden files in Tree View
data.body:
I have the following configurations:

``` cson
    'tree-view':
        hideIgnoredNames: false
        hideVcsIgnoredFiles: false
```

but unfortunately I'm still not able to see any hidden files in the Tree View.

data.title: Allow overriding "fn" key
data.body:
I'm trying to override the Fn key's functionality but no luck.

Here's what I have:

```
'fn-left': 'editor:move-to-beginning-of-screen-line'
```

I've tried various combinations, like `F`, `f`, `Fn` but none of them seem to work.

data.title: Coping folder content to one of its sub-folders
data.body:
In the Files Tree View, when coping folder "A" into one of its sub-folders "A/B"; Atom gets into an infinity loop in which the same content  of the main folder "A" will be duplicated in the target sub-folder "A/B/A" (the first time is as desired) then again copies itself into the newly created sub-sub-folder (A/B/A/"B").. and goes on and on...

E.g: Coping folder FONTS/ into FONTS/FA will produce: "FONTS/FA/FONTS/FA/FONTS/FA/FONTS/FA/FONTS/FA/..." and will not stop until you close Atom.

MOVED TO:
https://github.com/atom/tree-view/issues/509

data.title: "Search Issues" menu item doesn't work when not signed in into GitHub Website
data.body:
The Help / Search Issues menu item opens https://github.com/issues?q=+is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom in a browser. If I've not signed in into GitHub beforehand, this link returns a 404 for me.

I understand that you want users to search in _all_ Atom-related repositories, but it's probably more user-friendly to open https://github.com/atom/atom/issues instead, which works for anonymous users as well.

Probably the best solution would be for GitHub not to return a 404 but to redirect to the Sign In page instead. And you folks _are_ GitHub, right? :smiley: 

(Atom 1.0.0, Xubuntu 15.04)

data.title: ATOM erases PATH Variable when installing on Win7
data.body:
When I installed ATOM 1.0.0 and one of the previous versions on Windows7 using the Windows installer it erased the user PATH Variable instead of appending it to the existing PATH variable, which is kind of annoying. Sorry I forgot which was the version I installed before, but that behaviour is still present in 1.0.0.
Not sure if this behaviour is intended, I sincerely hope not!

Cheers,
Jan

data.title: On restart, Project folder persists in Tree view even after it is removed before closing application.
data.body:
**Configuration**
- System: Windows 7 (x64).
- Atom: 1.0.0 (Pre-built zipped package).
- No third-party packages.
- The same issue happens with atom --safe (Safe mode).

**Steps to reproduce**
- Open any project folder in Atom.
- Remove the project folder from tree view.
- Close the Atom application.
- Reopen the Atom application.

The removed Project folder in the Tree view persists even after it was removed before the Atom application was closed.

Since, after the project is removed from tree view, it is not supposed to come up again without specifying, I doubt that this is by design.

Can anybody confirm this behavior? Thanks!

data.title: The editor has crashed, just on opened
data.body: Hi, this is very undesearible issue, i recently installed atom-ctags and prety cool, but at some point my apps just got very slow, and now every time i open Atom it just stop and Crash. Im in a dead point. So in cases like this i would like to disable the problematic feature or something, but i cant, not in the editor for sure

data.title: Windows: With focus in editor window 'Alt' key doesn't toggle Menu bar
data.body: Windows: With focus in editor window 'Alt' key doesn't toggle Menu bar. With focus in the file browser pane, 'Alt' key _does_ toggle the menu bar. This bug is new to Atom 1.0.

data.title: Keyboard shortcut for switching between open windows on Mac OS X (CMD+`)
data.body:
Hello,
On Mac OS X, the default keyboard shortcut to switch between open windows in the app is [CMD+`], I tried this shortcut on a bunch of apps (Safari, Google Chrome..) and it works, but on Atom it doesn't.

Can you please add this functionality to Atom on Mac OS X?

Thanks

data.title: Emit will-insert-text event when pasting
data.body:
Packages like `go-to-line` [use the `::onWillInsertText` event](https://github.com/atom/go-to-line/blob/70428c943c4e1c5c2675d90e418bdcf2fd62833b/lib/go-to-line-view.coffee#L24) to stop invalid text from being inserted into a text-editor. Previously, this event was not emitted when pasting. This allowed invalid data to enter the editor in the `go-to-line` dialog.

Fixes atom/go-to-line#22

data.title: High CPU usage when editing a submodule of a massive superproject
data.body:
I have found that when editing a submodule of an extremely large superproject made of many small submodules, the following process takes up 100% cpu:

``` sh
/home/user/.local/share/atom/atom--evalrequire('/home/user/.local/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/coffee-cash/lib/coffee-cash.js').setCacheDirectory('/home/user/.atom/compile-cache/coffee');
require('/home/user/.local/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/coffee-cash/lib/coffee-cash.js').register();
require('/home/user/.local/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/coffeestack/index.js').setCacheDirectory('/home/user/.atom/compile-cache/coffee/source-maps');
require('/home/user/.local/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/task-bootstrap.js');⏎ 
```

It seems to be running on the entire superproject (which is absolutely massive) and finishes after some time, only to re-run whenever Atom regains focus, or when files change.

Using the debugger I confirmed that the repo being selected was the superproject rather than the current directory with the following:

``` sh
atom.project.getRepositories()[0].getPath()
=> "/home/user/superproject/.git"
```

Is there any way to change this behaviour, or turn it off for just that repository?

data.title: Guard against missing stdout/stderr on Task
data.body:
These appear to not always be there depending on the forked process.

Closes #7459
